Fig 7 One-step annealing synthesis of Co core-PdZn intermetallic shell composite as a bifunctional oxygen electrocatalyst for zinc-air batteries Jihong Jiang Investigation Conceptualization Methodology Data curation Writing – review & editing Visualization Yongqiang Fang Investigation Data curation Visualization Yiming Zhao Writing – review & editing Visualization Lianhua Zhao Project administration ⁎ Biyao Jin Conceptualization Writing – review & editing Project administration Supervision ⁎ College of Science, Yanbian University, Yanji 133002, China College of Science Yanbian University Yanji 133002 China College of Science, Yanbian University, Yanji 133002, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. PdZn intermetallic has excellent electrocatalytic properties due to the strong synergistic effects caused by the ordered arrangement of atoms. It is often synthesized by annealing Pd/ZnO in a hydrogen atmosphere. However, the low conductivity of ZnO crystals limits electron conduction, which is not conducive to electrocatalytic reactions. To avoid conductivity degradation, we annealed Zn2+-doped ZIF-67 adsorbed with Pd precursors in a nitrogen atmosphere. The key component, “ghost ZnO,” produced by the decomposition of ZIF during pyrolysis, was used to form intermetallic with Pd by reactive metal-support interaction. The remaining ZnO crystals were converted to amorphous ZnO or removed by sublimation. A composite structure of metal core-intermetallic shell was formed with the surface energy as the driving force. Co@o-PdZn/NC (Pdweight = 2.47 %) exhibited strong oxygen reduction reaction (ORR)/oxygen evolution reaction (OER) electrocatalytic activity (reversible oxygen overpotential of 0.771 V). Moreover, it provided great performance in rechargeable zinc-air batteries (ZABs). In this study, the reactive metal-support interaction (RMSI) between the key component “ghost ZnO” and Pd was used by a one-step annealing method, and the growth process of nanoparticles was precisely controlled using the difference in surface energy between the metals to properly design the catalyst surface structure. The synthesized metal core-PdZn intermetallic shell composite is a promising bifunctional oxygen electrocatalyst. These findings provide a new strategy for designing composites with a metal core-intermetallic shell structure. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords PdZn intermetallic Core-shell structures Bifunctional electrocatalysts Zn–air batteries Data availability Data will be made available on request. Introduction Rechargeable zinc-air batteries (ZABs) are devices that directly convert the chemical energy of fuel into electrical energy and are considered one of the most promising new energy sources. However, the application of ZABs is mainly limited by the slow kinetics of the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) during discharge and the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) during charging [1–4]. Neither Pd, which has the strongest ORR catalytic activity nor RuO2 and IrO2, which have the strongest OER catalytic activity, are suitable for ORR/OER bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysts in alkaline environments [5–8]. Developing low-cost, high-activity ORR/OER bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysts is important for advancing ZABs [9]. Thus, much research has been conducted on Pd-based electrocatalysts [10–12], mainly focusing on two points. One is to adjust the geometric structure of the material to increase the number of exposed active sites and the utilization of precious metals [13–16]. The other is to increase the intrinsic activity of a single active site, usually by introducing a second transition metal M (Fe, Zn, Co, etc.) to form an alloy with Pd [6,17,18]. In this method, Pd's electronic and geometric structure can be modified using the synergistic effect of Pd-M [19–21]. The order and distribution of the atoms on the catalyst surface, the morphology and geometry of the catalyst, and the electronic structure of the active elements largely determine the electrocatalytic performance [22–26]. Therefore, more accurately synthesizing nanoparticles has become a key research issue. Unlike disordered alloys, intermetallic compounds have long-range ordered atomic arrangements and definite stoichiometric numbers [27,28]. The ordered arrangement of the second group in intermetallic acts as a “fence” to isolate the parent element, sufficiently dispersing the active sites to expand the electrochemically active area. Thus, the geometry and electronic effects are better defined, facilitating the design, analysis, and optimization of electrocatalysts [29]. PdZn intermetallic has shown that introducing Zn shrinks the lattice of Pd; thus, the oxygen binding capacity of Pd and Zn is reduced, and the desorption of oxygen-containing intermediates in the catalytic reaction is accelerated, enhancing the ORR electrocatalytic activity. Tang et al. synthesized PdZn intermetallic (Pdweight = 48.25 %) by liquid phase co-reduction and annealing in a nitrogen atmosphere, and the product showed superior ORR electrocatalytic activity [30]. PdZn intermetallic is often synthesized by annealing Pd/ZnO in a hydrogen atmosphere. The conductivity of metal oxide carriers is generally not strong, which is unfavorable for electrocatalysis [31–34]. Carbon carriers can be used to improve conductivity [35–38]. Recently, metal-organic framework materials (MOFs) have attracted much attention due to their controllable porous shape, stability, and self-assembly. The carbon materials derived from the carbonization of MOFs can provide porous graphitic carbon skeletons and metal ion doping [39,40]. For example, Co@Pd/NC was synthesized with ZIF-67 carbon-derived porous carbon as a carrier and Co source [41]. In the past, a variety of intermetallic core-metal shell composites have been synthesized by seed growth, co-induction, electrodeposition, and one-pot wet chemistry methods [42–46]. However, they seldom studied the growth mechanism of intermetallic core-metal shell composites. In this study, the bimetal ZIF (Zn2+-doped ZIF-67) adsorbed with Pd precursors was transformed into a composite material by a one-step carbonization method. In the composite material, PdZn intermetallic was the shell, Co was the core, and the core-shell structured metal particles were loaded on NC material. The generated composite material was applied to ORR/OER electrocatalytic reaction, and the growth mechanism of nanoparticles was analyzed in detail. The ZnO crystals formed by the pyrolysis of ZIF undergo reactive metal-support interactions (RMSI) with the adsorbed Pd in a reducing environment, culminating in the formation of PdZn intermetallic compounds [47]. The d-band center of Pd was reduced by compressive strain on the Pd lattice to improve the catalytic performance. Excess ZnO crystals were converted to amorphous ZnO or reduced to metallic Zn and sublimated for removal, avoiding a reduction in the conductivity of the catalyst. Then, Co aggregated into nuclei under the action of surface energy, and PdZn intermetallic migrated and wetted the surface of Co to form a thin shell. This composite structure can increase the number of exposed active sites and the utilization of precious metals. Co@o-PdZn/NC (PdWeight = 2.47 %) exhibited high ORR electrocatalytic activity (Eonset = 0.915 V, E1/2 = 0.835 V), moderate OER catalytic activity (η 10 = 0.376 V), and a low potential difference between the ORR and OER (ΔE = 0.771 V). It performed well when applied to ZABs (maximum power density = 76.38 mW cm−2, specific capacity = 899.04 mA h g-1) and had strong reversibility (round-trip efficiency = 52.82 %). In conclusion, we synthesized a metal core-PdZn intermetallic shell catalyst with excellent electrocatalytic performance using RMSI and surface energy for propulsion. This catalyst is promising to be applied as a bifunctional oxygen electrocatalyst in ZABs. Furthermore, our study provides a new strategy for designing materials with a metal core-intermetallic shell structure. Experimental section Materials The chemicals used were analytically pure and were used directly without further purification. Cobalt nitrate hexahydrate (Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O), zinc nitrate hexahydrate (Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O), palladium(II) chloride, (PdCl2, Pd59–60%) and tetrabutylammonium hydroxide (C16H37NO, 25 wt.% in water) were all purchased from Beijing Innochem Technology Co., Ltd. Dichloromethane (CH2Cl2) and methanol (MeOH) were all purchased from Tianjin Comio Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. Concentrated hydrochloric acid (HCl, 37%) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Beijing Co., Ltd. Carbon Black (XC-72R) were all purchased from Cabot Corporation. 2-methylimidazole (C4H6N2), magnesium sulfate anhydrous (MgSO4), potassium hydroxide (KOH), zinc acetate dihydrate (Zn(Ac)2⋅2H2O) were all purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Reagent Co., Ltd. Nafion 117 containing solution (5 %) and sodium borohydride (NaBH4) were purchased from Shanghai Sigma-Aldrich Trading Co., Ltd. All deionized water was purified by Direct-Pure RO water purifier system. Synthesis of BIM-ZIF Co(NO3)2·6H2O (4.365 g) and Zn(NO3)2·H2O (1.487 g) were mixed and dissolved in methanol (120 ml). 2-Methylimidazole (3.284 g) was dissolved in methanol (40 ml), the two solutions were mixed and stirred, and the solution was dispersed well and left to stand for 24 h. The purple powder was collected after centrifugation at 4000 rpm for 13 min, washed with methanol three times, and dried under vacuum at 60 °C for 12 h. Synthesis of Pd@BIM-ZIF PdCl2 (0.2640 g) was added dropwise to concentrated hydrochloric acid (0.1 ml) and deionized water (50 ml), followed by CH2Cl2 (100 mL) and aqueous tetrabutylammonium hydroxide solution (0.75 ml). After magnetic stirring for 1 h, the organic layer was separated by a partition funnel, and the lower layer was removed from the water with anhydrous magnesium sulfate. The organic solution was added with ZIF (0.1 g), stirred magnetically for 24 h, and then the solid powder was withdrawn and retained. The solid powder was then dispersed into methanol (100 ml) and stirred for 24 h. The solid powder was collected after centrifugation at 4000 rpm for 15 min. The Pd@BIM-ZIF was collected after vacuum drying at 40 °C for 12 h. Synthesis of Co@o-PdZn/NC The Pd@BiM-ZIF was placed in a tube furnace (SKGL-1200C, Shanghai Jui-Jing Precision Instrument Manufacturing Co., Ltd.) under N2 atmosphere at 5 °C min-1 to 350 °C for 90 min, and then at 2 °C min-1 to 800 °C for 3 h to obtain the Co@o-PdZn/NC catalyst. We also synthesized Co@o-PdZn/NC-500, Co@o-PdZn/NC-600, and Co@o-PdZn/NC-700 with carbonization temperatures of 500 °C, 600 °C, and 700 °C, respectively, using the same strategy. o-PdZn/NC and Pd/Co/NC were synthesized using ZIF-8 and ZIF-67 instead of BIM-ZIF as precursors. To exclude the effect of the carrier we also used carbon black (0.1 g) as a carrier and stirred with Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.345 g) and Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.316 g) dispersed in PdCl2 (0.041 g) phase transferred from dichloromethane solution for 3 h, and slowly added aqueous sodium borohydride solution (10 ml, 0.4 M) dropwise under nitrogen atmosphere with continuous stirring. After 12 h, the solution was filtered and washed with deionized water. The collected black solid powder was vacuum dried at 60 °C for 12 h, put into a tube furnace, and calcined at 800 °C for 3 h with the same heating procedure to finally obtain Pd/Zn/Co/C. Characterizations The structure information was on the diffractometer (D/max-2000, Rigaku, Japan) with Cu-Kα radiation (λ = 1.54056 Å), and powder X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded. The Raman spectra were acquired on the Raman spectrometer (LabRAM HR Evolution, HORIBA Scientific, Japan) with a 532 nm laser excitation. The chemical information was obtained by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) using the electron spectrometer's monochromatic Al Kα radiation source (Escalab Xi+, Thermo Fisher, USA). The structural and morphological information of nanomaterials was obtained by transmission electron microscopy (Talos F200x, Thermo Fisher, USA) TEM images. The catalyst's specific surface area and average pore size were the nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms measured at 77 K using an automatic adsorption instrument (ASAP 2460, Micromeritics, USA). Electrochemical measurements All ORR electrochemical tests were performed on an electrochemical workstation (CHI-660D, Shanghai Chenhua Instruments Co., Ltd.). Testing was performed at ambient temperature using a conventional three-electrode system. A glassy carbon electrode (CHI-3 mm, Shanghai Chenhua Instruments Co., Ltd.), a Pt sheet, and an Ag/AgCl reference electrode stored in saturated KCl (3.0 M) were used as the working electrode, counter electrode, and reference electrode. 4 mg of electrocatalyst was homogeneously dispersed by sonication into 20 μL of Nafion solution (0.05 wt.%) and 0.98 ml of isopropanol. Spread 10 μL of catalyst ink drop onto the carbon surface of the rotating disk electrode and dry naturally. A rotating ring disk electrode (ATA-1B, Jiangsu Jiangfen Electroanalytical Instruments Co., Ltd.) was used, with 0.1 M KOH solution as the electrolyte, and N2/O2 was introduced for 30 min before the test. All voltages were converted to a reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE). The conversion calibration equation is: (1) E ( RHE ) = E ( Ag / AgCl ) + 0.0591 × pH + 0.2046 Calculation of electron transfer number and kinetic current density by Koutecky-Levich (K-L) plots from the LSV polarization curves of ORR. The formula is as follows: (2) 1 J = 1 J K + 1 J L = 1 J K + 1 B ω 1 / 2 (3) B = 0 . 62 n F C 0 ( D 0 ) 2 / 3 ν − 1 / 6 (4) J K = n F k C 0 Where J, Jk, and JL represent the rotating disk electrode current density, kinetic current density, and ultimate diffusion current density, respectively. ω is the electrode rotational speed, n is the electron transfer number, F is the Faraday constant (96,485 C mol-1), C0 is the oxygen saturation concentration in 0.1 M KOH (1.2 × 10-3 mol cm-3), D0 is the oxygen diffusion coefficient (1.9 × 10-5 cm2 s-1), ν is the kinematic viscosity of the electrolyte solution (0.01 cm2 s-1), and k is the rate constant of the ORR reaction. Evaluation of catalyst kinetics by Tafel plot based on ORR polarization curves. The formula is as follows: (5) η = a + b × log | j | Where η is the overpotential, a and b are the Tafel constants, and j is the rotating disk electrode current density. The value of the bilayer capacitance is calculated from the CV curves measured in the potential range without Faraday current and at different sweep speeds. The formula is as follows: (6) i c = v × C d l Where ic is the bilayer current, v is the scan rate, and Cdl is the bilayer capacitance. OER electrochemical tests were performed on an electrochemical workstation (CHI-660D, Shanghai Chenhua Instruments Co., Ltd.). A glassy carbon electrode (CHI-3 mm, Shanghai Chenhua Instruments Co., Ltd.), graphite rod, and Hg/HgO reference electrode were used as working electrodes, a counter electrode, and a reference electrode. An electrochemical test cuvette (50 ml, Tianjin Aida Technology Development Co., Ltd.) and a temperature-controlled magnetic stirrer (WCJ-802, Taixian, Jiangsu) were used, and a 1 M KOH solution was used as the electrolyte, and N2/O2 was introduced for 30 min before the test. All voltages were converted to a reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE). The conversion calibration formula and overpotential conversion formula are as follows: (7) E ( R H E ) = E ( H g / H g O ) + 0.0591 × p H + 0.098 (8) η = E ( R H E ) − 1.23 V Assembly of zinc-air batteries The zinc-air battery consists of an air electrode, an alkaline electrolyte solution, and a zinc anode. The zinc anode was 99.99 % polished zinc flakes, and the alkaline electrolyte solution was an aqueous solution of 6 M KOH and 0.2 M Zn(Ac)2. The air electrode was a carbon paper (P2, Changsha Spring New Energy Technology co. ltd, China) with a catalyst loading of 1.0 mg cm-2 and an effective area of 2 cm2. The constant current discharge test and charge/discharge cycle test were performed on a blue battery test system (CT3002A, Shenzhen Kejing Star Technology Company, China). The equation for Specific capacity (mAh·gZn −1) and Energy density (Wh·gZn −1) and Round-trip efficiency (%) are as follows: (9) Specific capacity = discharge current × working time mass of consumed zinc (10) Energy density = discharge current × working time × average voltage mass of consumed zinc (11) Round − trip efficiency = average discharge voltage average charging voltage Theoretical calculations This article used Materials Studio for density functional theory calculations. Based on the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) general function, the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) was used for the description of the electron exchange-related general function. A 6 × 6 × 7 k-point Monkhorst-Pack grid with a cut-off energy of 620 eV is set in the geometry optimization. The convergence tolerance for energy change, max force, and max displacement were 1.0 × 10−5 Ha, 0.03 Ha·Å−1, and 0.001 Å, respectively. Results and discussion We obtained a carbon-loaded metal@intermetallic compound core-shell structure composite (Co@o-PdZn/NC) by one-step pyrolysis (Fig. 1 ). In the core-shell structure, PdZn intermetallic was the shell, and metallic Co was the core. The carbon carrier was doped with abundant N and accompanied by carbon nanotubes. We used Zn2+-doped ZIF-67 as the sources of Zn and Co. The alkyl group of TBA2-[PdCl4] was fixed and dispersed on the cage structure of ZIF by strong hydrophobic interaction with the hydrophobic backbone of ZIF. Metal ions were reduced by carbon generated through high-temperature pyrolysis. We demonstrated the formation of PdZn intermetallic (PDF#065–9523) and Co monomer (PDF#015–0806) by X-ray diffraction (XRD) (Fig. 2 a). Through calculation (Table. S1 Supporting Information), we found that the lattice constant of Co@o-PdZn/NC shrunk 13.905 % in the c-direction compared to Pd/C. Compressive strain due to lattice contraction usually indicates low d-band centers and low oxygen binding energy, contributing to the ORR [48]. The Brunner-Emmet-Teller results (Table. S2 Supporting Information) showed that the high specific surface area (2225.28 m² g-1) and porous structure (Fig. S1, Supporting Information) of bimetal ZIF (BIM-ZIF) were partially reduced by the loading of Pd. We speculated that the hydrophobic particles formed after the complexation of [PdCl4]2− with the aliphatic chain of TBAOH during loading were attracted into the micropores of ZIF (3.4 Å) to occupy a certain micropore structure due to the capillary effect of the micropores. The Raman spectra of BIM-ZIF and Pd@BIM-ZIF showed the same conclusion (Fig. 2b). After the adsorption of Pd precursors, the Zn-N stretching frequency (ν Zn-N), Co-N stretching frequency (ν Co-N), and the puckering of the imidazole ring puckering had not shifted significantly. A new peak appeared at 2881 cm−1, which belongs to the CH stretching of adsorbed TBA2-[PdCl4] (Fig. S2, Supporting Information) [49]. This indicates that the complex TBA2-[PdCl4] is located in the center of the 6-ring pore composed of 2-methylimidazole through the methyl group in TBA+, and that the three -CH3 groups of MeIM all point to this position, which was formerly known as the "nanocage" [50–52] This chemisorption enhanced the interaction between TBA2-[PdCl4] and BIM-ZIF, which was retained after washing in methanol for 24 h. The significant decrease in the number of micropores after carbonization might be due to structural remodeling in the carbonization process. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) confirmed that Co@o-PdZn/NC and o-PdZn/NC formed the PdZn intermetallic. In the XPS full spectrum scan diagram (Fig. S3, Supporting Information) and its peak information table (Table S4, Supporting Information), it can be found that the surface of the catalyst is dominated by C (CAtomic% = 81.99 %), and the atomic content of O, Zn, N, Pd, and Co is 8.53 %, 2.08 %, 5.54 %, 0.51 %, and 1.35 %, respectively. The O element in Co@o-PdZn/NC is derived from nitrate in Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O and Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O during the synthesis of BIM-ZIF, and from airborne H2O adsorbed by Co@o-PdZn/NC. Fig. 2c shows the double-peak phenomenon of the high-resolution Pd 3d core-level spectrum of Co@o-PdZn/NC. The 3d5/2 electron peak of Pd is decomposed into peaks at 335.17, 336.02, and 336.79 eV, corresponding to the Pd0, PdZn intermetallic, and Pd-N, respectively. Pd0, PdZn intermetallic, and Pd-N account for 18.84 %, 60.35 %, and 20.82 % of the total Pd, respectively. The shift of binding energy to higher fields is generally due to the absence of electrons. The binding energy of PdZn intermetallic larger than that of Pd in the metallic state indicates the transfer of electrons from Pd to Zn. This is consistent with the results of previous studies [53,54]. The highly oxidized state of Pd was formed due to the transfer of electrons from Pd to N, resulting in a strong interaction. The Pd of o-PdZn/NC synthesized with ZIF-8 as precursor existed in three structures, Pd0 (335.46 eV), PdZn IMC (336.19 eV), and Pd-N (336.64 eV), respectively. This indicates that the presence of Co elements can promote the conversion of Pd0 to PdZn IMC. Compared with Co@o-PdZn/NC, the PdZn IMC peak position of o-PdZn/NC shifts 0.17 eV toward higher binding energy. This symbolizes a small amount of electron transfer from Pd to Co. Both Zn 2p mapping (Fig. 2d) and Zn LMM mapping (Fig. 2e) from Co@o-PdZn/NC show two electronic structures of Zn after deconvolution, with a high percentage of PdZn IMC (Zn 2p: 1021.56 eV, 78.23 %, Zn LMM: 497.99 eV, 78.82 %) and a small amount of ZnO (Zn 2p: 1022.61 eV, 21.63 %, Zn LMM: 494.55 eV, 21.18 %). The formation of PdZn IMC further verified the analysis results of Pd 3d spectra. The presence of ZnO corresponds to the small amount of M-O structure (529.47 eV, 20.35 %) found in the O 1s pattern (Fig. 2f). The remaining oxygen elements exist in the form of oxygen defects (531.74 eV, 42.65 %) and adsorbed water molecules (533.49 eV, 37.02 %). The abundant oxygen defect sites can optimize the adsorption energy of oxygen-containing intermediates and give the material higher ORR and OER catalytic activity [55–57]. In addition, Fig. 2g shows the high-resolution Co 2p core-level spectra of Co@o-PdZn/NC. After deconvolution, three states of Co, i.e., Co (778.89 eV, 16.44 %), Co-NC (781.62 eV, 41.31 %), and Co-N (780.11 eV, 42.24 %), can be presented. Four types of N in Co@o-PdZn/NC, including pyridine N (398.01 eV), Pd-N/Co-N (399.15 eV), pyrrole N (400.83 eV), and graphite N (401.68 eV), can be observed in Fig. 2h. Their percentages are 7.27 %, 40.63 %, 32.47 % and 17.19 %, respectively. The Raman spectrum (Fig. S4, Supporting Information) shows that the ID/IG = 1.112 for Co@o-PdZn/NC, indicating a high degree of graphitization, which can improve the conductivity and reduce the impedance of the catalyst. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) (Fig. 3 a) shows that, after high-temperature calcination, the dodecahedral structure of ZIF has partially collapsed, the metal particles have been embedded inside and on the surface of the NC carrier, and the carbon nanotube structure has been formed. The lattice structures with lattice spacings of 0.145, 0.205, 0.218, and 0.259 nm can be observed on the surfaces of the metal particles of Co@o-PdZn/NC in the high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) (Fig. 3b) images. They correspond to the (112), (101), (111) and (200) crystal planes of PdZn intermetallic, respectively. However, we found no crystalline surface of Co on the surfaces of the metal particles. The elemental mappings (Fig. 3c) of Co, Pd, and Zn in the selected region of metal particles of Co@o-PdZn/NC show that Co is clustered in the interiors of the metal particles, while Pd and Zn are divided on the surfaces of the particles. A core-shell structure with Co as the core and PdZn intermetallic as the shell has been formed for the metal particles. In the elemental mappings of other non-metallic elements (C, N, O) (Fig. S5, Supporting Information), we found that N and C are uniformly dispersed inside and outside the whole spherical particles as carriers, and O is mainly enriched in the spherical shell. The XPS analysis results and the elemental mappings of Zn and O indicate that the O elements enriched in the spherical shell mainly exist in the form of ZnO, oxygen defects, and adsorbed water molecules. ZnO in the spherical shell did not form an ordered crystal structure, so it does not have semiconductor properties and will not have a serious impact on the conductivity of the material [58]. To investigate the formation mechanism of the metal core-intermetallic shell structure, we characterized the Pd@BIM-ZIF at different calcination temperatures by XRD, TEM, and XPS. By comparing the XRD patterns (Fig. 4 a) at different carbonization temperatures, we found that the crystal structure of ZIF was damaged to some extent when the sample was calcinated at the plateau of 350 °C. The carbon produced by pyrolysis was reductive at high temperatures. Carbon first reduced the relatively electronegative Pd to small metal particles. The free Zn produced by the collapse of the ZIF structure was converted into ZnO crystals. When the temperature reached 500 °C, the crystal structure of ZIF was completely decomposed. The crystallinity of the (002) crystalline surface of graphitic carbon was low. We found that the dodecahedral structure of ZIF was partially preserved in the TEM (Fig. S6a, Supporting Information). In addition, the (111) crystalline surface of PdZn intermetallic was observed (Fig. S6d, Supporting Information). In the elemental mappings (Fig. 4b) of Pd, Co, and Zn in the selected ZIF region, we found that Pd and Zn were distributed synchronously, indicating the formation of intermetallic. PdZn intermetallic and Co separately coalesced into separate metal particles. Co (2.775 J cm−2) has a higher surface energy than Pd (2.24 J cm−2) and Zn (0.99 J cm−2). Therefore, the coalescence of Co was more obvious, and larger metal particles of Co formed [52]. Thus, the core-shell structure was formed because the mobility of the metal was enhanced as the temperature increased. The PdZn intermetallic migrated to the surface of the Co sphere driven by the surface energy. PdZn intermetallic fully wetted and encapsulated the Co core to form the final core-shell structure [59]. To avoid the effect of carbon carriers on the formation of PdZn intermetallic, we used carbon black as a carrier to prepare Pd/Zn/Co/C. We found that Pd was similarly converted to PdZn intermetallic after NaBH4 reduction and annealing in a nitrogen atmosphere at 800 °C for 3 h. The peaks of PdZn intermetallic can be observed in the XRD plots (Fig. S7a, Supporting Information), indicating that the formation of intermetallic is independent of the type of carbon carriers By analyzing the high-resolution Pd 3d core-level spectrum of Co@o-PdZn/NC-500 (Fig. 4c), we found that Pd0 (41.08 %) was partially converted to PdZn intermetallic (38.27 %) and Pd-N (20.64 %). The formation of PdZn intermetallic in Co@o-PdZn/NC-500 was further verified. Fig. 4d shows the Zn LMM Auger electron spectra of Co@o-PdZn/NC-500, with 498.36 eV and 495.26 eV corresponding to PdZn intermetallic and ZnO, respectively. No metallic Zn was found, further indicating that the key to generating PdZn intermetallic is the appearance of ZnO crystals. The ZnO crystals were not used as a base material in the synthesis process but as a more stable intermediate resulting from the decomposition of BIM-ZIF during the annealing process. As the annealing session proceeded, ZnO was gradually reduced by RMSI under the excitation of Pd and diffused into the lattice of Pd to form an ordered structure. The crystal structure of ZnO was gradually disrupted and eventually changes to a disordered amorphous state. Therefore, those transient ZnO crystals, which play a crucial role in the formation of PdZn IMC, were called “ghost ZnO”. The characteristic peak of Co0 was observed after deconvolving the high-resolution Co 2p core-level spectrum of Co@o-PdZn/NC-500 (Fig. 4e). Therefore, we speculate that RMSI occurred between Pd and ZnO at high temperatures, which induces electron transfer between Pd and ZnO. This led to preferential reduction of Zn and formation of intermetallic with Pd. In contrast, for NC carriers (Fig. 4f), heating resulted in the conversion of pyridine N (398.11 eV, 42.48 %) to pyrrole N (399.71 eV, 9.51 %) and graphite N (400.71 eV, 13.32 %). The increase in the number of graphite structures also improved the conductivity of the catalyst. To summarize, there are two reasons for forming the metal core-intermetallic shell structure. One reason is the role of environmental factors. The high-temperature environment provided enough energy for the Zn atoms to break the energy barrier required for diffusion. BIM-ZIF in the process of Pd adsorption, Zn2+ and Co2+ were transferred to the solution in the presence of free TBA+. This phenomenon caused numerous defective bits in the ZIF structure and reduced the diffusion of Zn to lower the spatial potential resistance. The other reason is the influence of the intrinsic properties of the metals. Pd and Co are in group VIII of the periodic table and are buffer elements. Zn is in group IIB and is an electron-excess element. When Pd and Zn formed intermetallic since the electronegativity of Pd (2.20) was higher than that of Zn (1.65), Pd and Zn were linked by a bond with ionic bonding properties. Thus, the electrons of Zn were naturally shifted to Pd, making Pd partially negatively charged and Zn partially positively charged. To return to the stable state of electrical neutrality, Pd transferred electrons to Zn. These findings are consistent with previous studies [60–62]. Most importantly, the RMSI on the Pd/ZnO interface in a reducing environment promoted the electron transfer between Pd and Zn. The close interaction between the two metals was further strengthened. The reduced Zn then diffused into the lattice of Pd to form the atomically ordered PdZn intermetallic. The emergence and diffusion kinetics of ZnO crystals are key factors in the formation of intermetallic compounds. The reaction mechanism is as follows: 2Pd + 2ZnO + C = 2PdZn + CO2 ↑ With the annealing procedure, Pd0 was gradually transformed into PdZn intermetallic. Pd was fixed on the NC backbone through the Pd-N bond. ZnO crystals were removed by conversion to amorphous ZnO or sublimation through reduction to metallic Zn. Mutually independent Co particles and PdZn intermetallic particles underwent Ostwald Ripening at high temperatures. With surface energy as the driving force, Pd and Zn with low surface energy carried part of O and migrated to the surfaces of the Co nuclei for cladding and were uniformly stretched into a thin shell. Finally, the core-shell structure with Co as the core and PdZn intermetallic as the shell was formed. The density of states of Pd was calculated after optimizing the geometrical structure (Fig. S10, Supporting Information). The figure shows that the d-band broadening of Pd becomes dramatically narrower after forming PdZn intermetallic, and the d-band center of Pd is reduced from −2.111 eV to −2.774 eV. Nørskov et al. found that Pt binds too strongly to oxygen to cause difficult desorption of oxygen-containing intermediates in the ORR reaction. The electron transfer from PdZn IMC to Pd via Zn will reduce the d-band center of Pd, which can weaken the degree of difficult desorption of oxygen-containing intermediates during the ORR reaction. This is favorable to ORR electrocatalysis [63,64]. The unique atomic arrangement of PdZn IMC enhances the cleavage of OO bond, which in turn further improves the ORR catalytic activity [65]. The cyclic voltammogram curves (Fig. 5 a) show that the oxide reduction potential of Co@o-PdZn/NC (0.72 V) is higher than that of o-PdZn/NC (0.68 V) and the commercially available 20 % loading of Pd/C (0.70 V). The positive shift of the oxide reduction peak represents the lowering of the d-band center of Pd and the decrease in oxygen adsorption capacity, which is beneficial for the ORR. We evaluated the catalytic activity of the catalysts by linear scanning voltammetry using a rotating disk electrode in 0.1 M of O2 - saturated KOH solution at 1600 rpm. As shown in the ORR polarization curves (Fig. 5b), the onset potential of Co@o-PdZn/NC (Eonset = 0.915 V) is much higher than that of Co/Pd/NC (Eonset = 0.896 V), o-PdZn/NC (Eonset = 0.879 V), Pd/C (Eonset = 0.885 V) and Pt/C (Eonset = 0.894 V). Co@o-PdZn/NC has the highest ultimate diffusion current density of 6.703 mA cm−2. Co@o-PdZn/NC (Pdweight = 2.47 %) has ORR catalytic activity, including onset oxidation potential, half-wave potential, and ultimate diffusion current density, comparable to that of Pd/C and Pt/C (Pd/Ptweight = 20 %). The electrocatalytic activity of the catalyst was improved, while the cost was greatly reduced. The whole reaction process in the polarization curve of the ORR can be divided into three stages. The first one is the high potential onset phase, controlled by the intrinsic kinetic properties of the catalyst. The second one is the mixing phase, which is controlled by kinetics and diffusion. The third one is the plateau phase, controlled by diffusion only. Since the ORR is a complex reaction involving multi-step electron transfer, it is kinetically slow. Thus, we prefer catalysts to accelerate the kinetics of the ORR. Jk represents the kinetic velocity of the catalyst when performing ORR catalysis to some extent. We compared the Jk values of different samples at a high potential (0.9 V) controlled only by the kinetic properties. Fig. 5c shows that the Jk value of Co@o-PdZn/NC (1.23 V) is the highest at the high potential, which is much higher than that of Pt/C (0.56 V) and Pd/C (0.77 V). Additionally, the Tafel slope is one of the criteria to measure catalyst kinetics. A low Tafel slope represents a high kinetic rate of the ORR. Fig. 5d displays that the Tafel slope of Co@o-PdZn/NC (51.19 mV dec−1) is smaller than that of Pt/C (59.37 mV dec−1) and Pd/C (76.25 mV dec−1). The above illustrates the excellent catalytic activity and fast kinetics of Co@o-PdZn/NC in the ORR catalytic process. The reaction paths of the ORR also impact the kinetic rate. The two-electron reduction pathway can not only increase the overpotential of the reaction (ΔE = 0.547 V) but also corrode the catalyst and the organic septum in the metal-air cell through the intermediate product H2O2. Therefore, we prefer direct four-electron reduction using O2 [3,4,66]. However, the dissociation energy of the intermediates O2 - and O2 2- (98.7 kJ mol−1) in the two-electron reduction pathway is much lower than that of O2 (498 kJ mol−1) in the four-electron reduction pathway. The two-electron reduction is more likely to occur when the catalytic activity is weak [67]. To analyze the electron transfer number (n) of Co@o-PdZn/NC with strong electrocatalytic activity, we used the Koutecky-Levich equation (Fig. S11, Supporting Information). The result demonstrated that the electron transfer number (n) values of Co@o-PdZn/NC (n = 4.076), Pt/C (n = 3.782), and Pd (n = 3.95) were similar. The electrochemically active area is also an important indicator of the catalytic performance of the catalyst. In this paper, we used cyclic voltammetry to determine the change rate of the current density with the scan rate (Fig. 5e) at non-faradaic potentials (0.37 - 0.47 V). The value of the bilayer capacitance (Cdl) of Co@o-PdZn/NC was calculated to be 23.68 mF cm−2. Its high electrochemically activity area is attributed to the metal core-intermetallic shell structure that leaks many active sites. Using the chrono-current method, we plotted the long-term stability test (Fig. 5f) to explore the stability of the samples. As shown in the figure, the current dropped to 86.9 % of its initial value for o-PdZn/N, indicating that ordered structures can improve durability. However, after the addition of Co, the stability decreased to 69.8 %, which is similar to that of Pd/C (69.4 %). It may be because the composite structure of Co@o-PdZn/NC is not stable in electrochemical activity. The stability of the structure needs to be improved. In summary, the excellent ORR electrocatalytic activity of Co@o-PdZn/NC is attributed to three reasons. The first one is the atomically ordered PdZn intermetallic that formed a thin shell layer on a carbon-doped carbon carrier. The ligand and geometric effects of Zn and Pd optimized the electronic structure and compressed the crystal structure of Pd, reducing the d-band center and oxygen binding energy. The second one is the introduction of cheap Co as a nuclear layer, which can improve the utilization of precious metals and reduce production costs. The second aspect is that the introduction of Co can not only promote the conversion of Pd0 to PdZn at high temperatures, increase the content of PdZn IMC but also form a core-shell structure with Co as the core after carbonization. In the second aspect, the introduction of Co not only promotes the conversion of Pd0 to PdZn IMC at high temperatures and increases the content of PdZn IMC, but also forms a core-shell structure with Co as the nucleus after carbonization. The high conductivity of Co (IACS: Co= 27.6 %, Pd = 16 %, Zn = 28.27 %, Cgraphite = 6.5 %) was used as a core to improve the conductivity of the catalyst. The protection of the Co core by the PdZn IMC shell weakens the leaching of transition metal ions during the electrocatalytic process. The heterostructure at the interface between the Co core and the PdZn IMC shell optimizes the electron configuration through interfacial electron transfer and regulates the adsorption and desorption process of the reaction intermediates [68]. In addition, Co can serve as a second active site of the ORR to further enhance the catalytic activity. The third one is the carbon nanotube structures spawned by metal particles, which can increase electrical conductivity and create channels for electron transfer in catalytic reactions [19–21]. In addition, the introduction of base metal Co and the support of PdZn IMC shell as a spherical core not only improves the utilization of precious metal Pd but also significantly reduces the production cost of the catalyst. In addition, we drew the OER polarization curves of different catalysts in 1 M of O2-saturated KOH solution (Fig. 5g) with a scan rate of 5 mV s-1. As shown in the figure, when the current density is 10 mA cm-2, the overpotential η10 of Co@o-PdZn/NC is 0.376 V, indicating high OER catalytic activity. At the high potential of OER, the catalyst is susceptible to transition metal leaching and degradation. Considering the leaching phenomenon of transition metal ions at high potentials, we performed XPS characterization of Co@o-PdZn/NC-LSV after LSV (1∼1.9 V vs RHE) scanning [69,70]. As shown in Fig. 6 , a comparison of the elemental content of the surfaces before and after electrocatalysis revealed that slight leaching of Co (CoAtomic% = 0.64 %) and Pd (PdAtomic% = 0.17 %) occurred, while Zn (ZnAtomic% = 0.85 %) leached relatively more. The higher levels of K (KAtomic% = 22.85 %) and O (OAtomic% = 18.98 %) were attributed to the interference of the KOH electrolyte solution in the OER test environment. The increase of Pd0 (21.45 %) content in the Pd 3d region indicates that the ordered structure of the partially Pd-enriched detachment from the PdZn intermetallic compound in the electrochemical reaction. The shift of PdZn (336.11 eV) and Pd0 (335.25 eV) toward higher binding energies of 0.08 ∼ 0.09 eV reflects the partial oxidation of Pd during the electrochemical process. The loss of Co0 (14.19 %) in the Co 2p region with the stable retention of Co-N, Co-NC, and Pd-N structures then indicates that the chemical bond formed between the metal and NC carriers can enhance the metal-carrier interaction. This chemical bonding will improve the stability of the material and attenuate the leaching of metal ions in the electrochemical reaction. The core-shell structure of Co@o-PdZn/NC would also further enhance the protection of the Co core that acts as a support and second active site. The shift of Co0 (779.14 eV), Co-NC (782.58 eV), and Co-N (780.47 eV) toward higher binding energies of 0.25 ∼ 0.96 eV also reflect the partial oxidation of Co during the electrochemical process. The substantial decrease of ZnO proportion in the Zn 2p (15.48 %), Zn LMM (16.55 %), and O 1s (2.65 %) profiles, while the PdZn content remained largely unchanged, suggesting that the leaching of Zn ions was dominated by disordered ZnO. The active sites PdZn IMC and Co-NC of Co@o-PdZn/NC did not undergo large leaching before and after electrochemistry, indicating that it had certain electrochemical stability at high potential. The key parameter to measure the catalytic activity of the bifunctional oxygen electrocatalyst is the potential difference (ΔE) between the half-wave potential of the ORR and the overpotential η10 of the OER. The ∆E value of Co@o-PdZn/NC (0.771 V) is much lower than that of most currently reported noble metal-based bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysts. Based on the strong ORR and OER catalytic activity of Co@o-PdZn/NC, we simulated its operation in actual use by assembling ZABs (Fig. 7 a). We used a zinc plate as the anode, composite carbon paper coated with the catalyst as the cathode, and 6 M KOH + 0.2 M Zn(Ac)2 as the electrolyte to perform the test in the ambient atmosphere. Using the Blue Power Cell Test System, we found that the open-circuit voltage of ZABs (Co@o-PdZn/NC) was 1.44 V, which was slightly lower than the open-circuit voltage (OCV) of ZABs (Pt/C + RuO2) (1.46 V). The ZABs (Co@o-PdZn/NC) obtained a specific capacity of 899.04 mA h g-1 and a corresponding energy density of 1032.43 Wh kg-1 at a discharge current density of 10 mA cm-2, which were much higher than those of ZABs (Pt/C+RuO2) (823.73 mA h g-1 and 903.70 Wh kg-1) (Fig. 7b). In addition, the peak power and current density of Co@o-PdZn/NC (76.38 mW cm-2 and 114 mA cm-2) were found to be higher than those of Pt/C+RuO2 (51.65 mW cm-2 and 81.35 mA cm-2) in the discharge polarization curves (Fig. 7c) with a scan rate of 5 mV s-1. The superior ORR catalytic performance of Co@o-PdZn/NC was further verified. To explore the reversibility of ZABs (Co@o-PdZn/NC), we performed charge and discharge tests at a current density of 10 mA cm-2 (Fig. 7d). and the cycle efficiency was 52.82 %, higher than that of Pt/C+RuO2 (47.19 %). The above results showed that the Co@o-PdZn/NC developed in this study had good activity and reversibility as a bifunctional oxygen electrocatalyst for ZABs. Conclusions In this study, we synthesized Co@o-PdZn/NC with metal as the core and PdZn intermetallic as the shell. The BIM-ZIF with TBA2-[PdCl4] adsorbed was used as a precursor. After annealing, an ORR/OER bifunctional catalyst with PdZn intermetallic as the shell, Co as the core, and nitrogen-doped carbon as the carrier was formed. Different reduction order and diffusion behavior of metals during annealing by using the difference of RMSI and surface energy. The Zn in BIM-ZIF diffused into the lattice of Pd to form the atomically ordered PdZn intermetallic. The lattice spacing between Pd and Pd in the spatial structure was reduced. The d-band center of Pd was reduced by the electron transfer between Pd and Zn in the electronic structure. Co in BIM-ZIF became the core of metal particles after carbonization. Furthermore, the production costs of catalysts were reduced. The results showed the excellent ORR catalytic activity of Co@o-PdZn/NC (Pdweight = 2.47 %) exhibits, with onset oxidation potential (Eonset = 0.915 V) and half-wave potential (E1/2 = 0.835 V) higher than those of commercial Pt/C and Pd/C and showed its faster kinetics. The low bifunctional potential difference (∆E = 0.771 V) enabled Co@o-PdZn/NC to perform well in ZABs. The specific capacity and power density of Co@o-PdZn/NC (899.04 mA h g-1 and 76.38 mW cm-2) were higher than those of Pt/C+RuO2 (823.73 mA h g-1 and 51.65 mA cm-2). In addition, Co@o-PdZn/NC had no significant performance degradation after 1000 charge/discharge cycles. Therefore, the nitrogen-doped carbon-loaded composite Co@o-PdZn/NC with metal as the core and PdZn intermetallic as the shell has great application prospects in the field of zinc-air batteries. This study provides new ideas for designing composites with a metal core-intermetallic shell structure. coredata.dc:description: PdZn intermetallic has excellent electrocatalytic properties due to the strong synergistic effects caused by the ordered arrangement of atoms. It is often synthesized by annealing Pd/ZnO in a hydrogen atmosphere. However, the low conductivity of ZnO crystals limits electron conduction, which is not conducive to electrocatalytic reactions. To avoid conductivity degradation, we annealed Zn2+-doped ZIF-67 adsorbed with Pd precursors in a nitrogen atmosphere. The key component, “ghost ZnO,” produced by the decomposition of ZIF during pyrolysis, was used to form intermetallic with Pd by reactive metal-support interaction. The remaining ZnO crystals were converted to amorphous ZnO or removed by sublimation. A composite structure of metal core-intermetallic shell was formed with the surface energy as the driving force. Co@o-PdZn/NC (Pdweight = 2.47 %) exhibited strong oxygen reduction reaction (ORR)/oxygen evolution reaction (OER) electrocatalytic activity (reversible oxygen overpotential of 0.771 V). Moreover, it provided great performance in rechargeable zinc-air batteries (ZABs). In this study, the reactive metal-support interaction (RMSI) between the key component “ghost ZnO” and Pd was used by a one-step annealing method, and the growth process of nanoparticles was precisely controlled using the difference in surface energy between the metals to properly design the catalyst surface structure. The synthesized metal core-PdZn intermetallic shell composite is a promising bifunctional oxygen electrocatalyst. These findings provide a new strategy for designing composites with a metal core-intermetallic shell structure.
coredata.dc:title: One-step annealing synthesis of Co core-PdZn intermetallic shell composite as a bifunctional oxygen electrocatalyst for zinc-air batteries
